prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking whether the author of this situation is in the wrong. Let me start by reading through the scenario carefully.

The author (a guy) and his girlfriend live together. He pays all the bills because she only works part-time. Recently, they went to get takeout, but he forgot his wallet. He asked her to pay, and she reacted with an "ugly" attitude, sounding disgusted and put out. He's upset that she didn't pitch in for a $40 meal and now wants her to start paying some bills, even if it's not much. The user thinks the author is in the wrong and wants to know if the author is indeed at fault.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their relationship. They live together, so splitting expenses is a common topic. The author has been paying everything, which might be okay if both parties agreed on that arrangement. However, the girlfriend only works part-time, so maybe she doesn't earn enough to contribute financially. But he's pointing out that her part-time income could still cover some expenses, even if it's not a lot.

The key issue here is the incident where the author made her pay for the takeout. He's upset because of her reaction, which he found ungrateful. But he's now using that single incident to demand she start paying more bills. The question is whether his reaction is justified.

From the author's perspective, he might feel that he's been carrying all the financial burden and wants her to contribute, even if it's small. On the other hand, the girlfriend might feel that because she earns less, she's not in a position to help, especially since he's already paying all the bills. Her reaction could stem from feeling taken advantage of or unappreciated, especially if this is the first time he's asked her to pay anything.

The author is making a big deal over a $40 meal. That's not a huge amount. Maybe he's using this as an excuse to shift responsibility onto her, which might not be fair. If the relationship has always had him pay everything, suddenly expecting her to start contributing because of one incident could be seen as unfair, especially if there's no prior discussion about splitting costs.

Also, the author's frustration with her reaction might indicate that there's an underlying issue about expectations. If he never discussed the financial arrangements, then holding her accountable after a single incident could be his mistake. The principle of fairness is important here. If they're in a partnership, it's reasonable to expect both to contribute, but the approach matters. Instead of using a $40 meal to demand more, a conversation about sharing expenses might have been better.

On the other hand, the author might be right in wanting her to contribute if they've been in a relationship where she's not contributing at all. But his reaction seems to be based on one incident and his own unresolved feelings about the financial arrangement. The problem is whether his approach is fair. Demanding she pay more bills over a single incident without prior discussion is likely to be seen as inconsiderate.

So, considering all this, the author is probably in the wrong. He's using a minor incident to justify a significant change in the financial arrangement without considering the existing power dynamic or discussing it with her. His frustration might be valid, but his approach is not fair. Therefore, the answer would be A.
